Good point! While virtual happy hours and team-building activities can be fun, they may not be enough to truly engage remote workers and foster a sense of belonging to the team. Here are additional strategies that companies can use to ensure their remote workers are engaged and feel like they are an important part of the team:

1. Regular one-on-one Meetings: Scheduled one-on-one meetings between remote workers and their manager or team leader can be very effective in keeping remote workers engaged. Personal interaction promotes engagement, enhances the relationship between the remote worker and their manager, whilst also providing opportunities for feedback and problem-solving.

2. Encourage Communication: Companies should encourage communication among remote workers, and between remote workers and their in-office colleagues. This could be accomplished through the use of chat apps, video conferencing software, and collaboration tools to make it easier for team members to communicate, collaborate and share feedback.

3. Use Volunteer Activities: Volunteer activities are another way to promote team building and create a sense of belonging. Encouraging employees to volunteer together helps them build teamwork skills, strengthen relationships, and promotes feelings of social connectedness, especially when it’s a cause that everyone feels passionate about.

4. Utilize Peer Recognition Programs: Peer recognition programs can help remote workers feel valued and appreciated. Such recognition programs could include shout-out programs where workers are given an opportunity to recognize and appreciate their colleagues.

5. Provide Opportunities for Skill Development: Companies can provide remote workers with opportunities to develop new skills and knowledge, which can be both beneficial for their professional growth and help them feel more engaged with the company's goals.

By implementing these additional strategies, companies can ensure their remote workers are engaged, feel valued, and a sense of belonging to the team.
